results.title: Sitting right
results.brief_description: Opening with a series of incidents in which girls are rebuked for poor posture, the film presents examples of good habits which are juxtaposed against bad ones. The film suggests that women can improve their posture by observing movie stars and other well poised role models. Stresses the importance of maintaining a healthy mental attitude to appearance, by devoting regular time to practicing good posture, until it become effortless and automatic. Shows how to sit down and how to stand up with particular attention to leg, arm and head positions. An essential guide for any women, or man, aspiring to ladylike poise and grace.

results.title: Sitting pretty: how to paint a portrait
results.creator_credit: Bell and Howell and Randolph Coats
results.brief_description: A dynamic and colorful demonstration of painting a portrait by one of America’s most popular portrait artists, Randolph Coats. A model is posed in various different lightings, before the artist decides on the one which suits his purpose best; then the process of painting a portrait is followed step by step to its completion.

results.title: Sitcom (D)
results.creator_credit: Fidelite Productions, Olivier Delbosc, Marc Missonnier and Francois Ozon
results.brief_description: An outrageously twisted black comedy from French writer-director Francois Ozon, documenting how the bourgeois existence of a French family is turned upside-down after the father brings home a pet rat. The film opens with the father, Jean (Francois Marthouret), gunning down his entire family at his birthday party. Flashing back several months earlier, the sordid story begins to unfold as mother Helene (Evelyne Dandry) shows the new Spanish maid, Maria, around the house. At dinner, son Nicolas (Adrien de Van) abruptly announces that he is gay. His sister, Sophie (Adrien’s real-life sister, Marina de Van), attempts suicide, leaving herself a bitter paraplegic, while her boyfriend, David, tries to prove his undying love to her by engaging in a series of humiliating sadomasochistic experiences. The situation becomes more complicated when Maria refuses to do any cleaning, and gets caught seducing David, and her teacher husband, Abdu, becomes Nicolas’ sexual mentor. Helene, unable to understand what has happened to her family but determined to resolve matters, decides to begin by having sex with her son to “cure” him of his homosexuality. Through all this mayhem, Jean manages to stay calm, until he is forced by the family to give up his beloved pet rat. In a scene reminiscent of “The Cook, the Thief, his Wife and her Lover”, the rat is disposed of, a bizarre act that has extraordinary consequences for the entire household. “Sitcom” was screened in the International Critics Week section at the 1998 Cannes Film Festival. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: Sit down one place
results.brief_description: Compares the nomads, a group of 500 Aborigines led by a white man, Don McLeod, in the Pilbara, Western Australia, with the Mugarinya people led by Aborigine, Peter Coffin. The former have little governmental help and find it difficult to come to terms with the disintegration of their culture, the latter run their own station and receive assistance.

results.title: Sisters of Gion = Gion no shimai [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Daiichi Eiga, Masaichi Nagata and Kenji Mizoguchi
results.brief_description: Mizoguchi’s sympathetic film of the plight of women in pre-War society centres on two geisha sisters; Umekichi (Isuzu Yamada), and Omacha (Yoko Umemura). The sisters differ not only in age, but in the attitudes to their profession and the clients they service. The younger sister, Omacha, is disillusioned about men and relationships and actively sets out to destroy a young clerk. The elder sister becomes romantically involved with one of her former clients, bankrupt merchant Omocha (Yoko Umemura), and finds temporary happiness. Ultimately, Mizoguchi suggests they are both victims to circumstance and the position of women in society. Gion refers to the Kyoto district where the sisters work. In Japanese with English subtitles.

results.title: Sisters in arms
results.brief_description: 100 years of Australian military nursing is celebrated in this collection of personal accounts and archival footage. The contribution of Australian nurses has spanned across many wars; the Boer War, Great War, World War 2, as well as battles in the Mediterranean, New Guinea and Vung Tau. It is from these often tragic environments that stories of hope, courage, duty, adventure and romance emerge and are shared with the viewer. Narrated by Geraldine Dooge.

results.title: Sisters are doin' it for themselves: women in the contemporary music industry
results.creator_credit: Greg Ferguson, Lindy Morrrison, AUSMUSIC and Conspiracy Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Basic music industry skills”.
Module 4.5. Pursuing a career in the rock music industry is not easy for women and the path to success is often difficult. Lindy Morrison, an ex-band member of the groups The Go-Betweens and Cleopatra Wong, interviews women who have worked in artistic and non-artistic roles in the industry. In terms of gender balance, radio airplay, income and participant numbers, there is still room for improvement. Key female industy figures featured include Kylie Minogue, Wendy Matthews and Tina Arena, along with ‘pioneer’ artists such as Judy Stone, Laurel Lee and Little Pattie.

results.title: Sisters [NTSC] [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: American International Pictures (AIP), Edward Pressman and Brian De Palma
results.brief_description: Brian De Palma’s first foray into the horror genre continues the directors fascination with Alfred Hitchcock, serving up his own twisted take on Hitchcock’s seminal shocker, Psycho and a bit of Rear window thrown in for good measure. (Hitchcock’s long time composer Bernard Herrmann also provides the score for Sisters) Sisters gets off to an auspicious start with a bizarre game show where we first meet the shy and introverted Danielle (Margot Kidder). On this rather perverse show (which seems to centre around voyeurism, a favorite De Palma theme) she meets Phillip (Lisle Wilson). The two end up back at Danielle’s apartment, much to the displeasure of her ex-husband (William Finley) and her rather unhinged twin sister Dominique (also played by Kidder). Not to give anything away, Phillip is brutally murdered soon after, which is witnessed by her journalist neighbour Grace (Jennifer Salt). Unfortunately Grace has a hard time convincing the authorities that a murder has taken place when the body mysteriously disappears out of Danielle’s apartment. De Palma reaches deep into his cinematic bag of tricks, offering a dazzling display of split-screens, flashbacks, superimposed imagery and lurid dream sequences, in this enthralling slice of grand guignol. Cast includes: Charles Durning, Dolph Sweet, Lisle Wilson.

results.title: Sister, if you only knew
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Suzanne Baker and Janet Isaac
results.brief_description: The theme of this film is about the pressures on Aboriginal women living in the city…what effect it has also on their men and their children. The film focuses on four women and the part they played in the movement demanding more equal opportunities for urban Aboriginals, for better conditions, the removal of discriminatory Acts, etc. Although life is difficult the women seem to survive better than the men. Their humour, intelligence and resilience in the face of life’s difficulties often surprise people who see this film. The women are Leila Rankine (Music and Tribal Culture Education), Ruby Hammond (Legail Aid), Mary Williams (Aboriginal Kindergarten) and Gladys Elphick, MBE (President, Aboriginal Women’s Council).

results.title: Sister Wendy's odyssey. -Volume 2
results.creator_credit: BBC, Nicholas Rossiter and John Hooper
results.brief_description: Sister Wendy Beckett has a passion for art and leaves the confines of her religious silence in search of the art treasures she has found in books and on postcards. For Sister Wendy art represents a window to something greater, and when one is looking at art, one is looking at God. In this second part of the odyssey in which Sister Wendy openly shares her first impressions of seeing the art she’s admired, she visits Wilton House, Birmingham, and Edinburgh stopping to reflect on her favourite pieces. PLEASE NOTE: THERE IS A CLOCK TIMER BETWEEN EACH EPISODE ON THE TAPE.
